2246.68.text:

2248.42.text:
of layers in the neural

2250.70.text:

2252.83.text:
of the output of

2256.16.text:

2257.62.text:

2265.40.text:
all the way up to eyes, and

2634.29.text: by that point, but not always.

2636.43.text:
Sometimes I have to do the
full resolution a few times

2639.69.text:
to get what I really
want, especially when it

2642.53.text:
comes to the intensity and
the scale of the feature.

2644.70.text:
Sometimes I've got to
really tweak with that.

2646.81.text:
JOSEPH SMARR: This is
what I was just thinking.

2648.06.text:
I did the simplest
possible thing

2649.62.text:
of expose all the
parameters in UI.

2651.18.text:
That's like when
you don't really

2653.25.text:
You just give them
all the controls.

2654.94.text:
Normally that's not a
good idea as an engineer

2656.56.text:
if you're building a
really usable product,

2658.35.text:
but it allowed Dan to do a
lot more matching of the style

2661.08.text:
to the picture than I would have
originally thought possible.

2663.62.text:
And one that I
love is he also got

2665.36.text:
commissioned to build a piece
for a startup in Guadalajara,

2669.31.text:
And so while we
were there, we went

2670.77.text:
to this is amazing old cathedral
in the center of Guadalajara.

2673.70.text:
And he took this interior,
which I think he maybe

2675.28.text: showed in one of the videos.

2676.45.text: And he did this dreaming style.

2678.45.text:
It's kind of
spirally, and it looks

2680.29.text:
like you're having a
religious experience in there.

2682.41.text:
So for me that perfectly
works with the subject matter.

2684.95.text:
DANIEL AMBROSI: Yeah, that was
a good example because we really

2687.57.text:
want to be careful not
to do anything that

2689.97.text:
would be offensive
to religious people,

2693.03.text:
and conversely hoped
to find something

2696.66.text:
that they would
even be inspired by

2700.95.text: And I think we found something.

2703.74.text: It took a lot of tries though.

2705.54.text:
The amazing thing is
we were able to do

2707.34.text:
all of that to completion
from our Westin hotel

2712.35.text:
Because the robot is
up in the cloud and I

2715.74.text:
could access it with
any internet connection.

2730.37.text:
One's a little bit further
out than an engineering.

2735.77.text:
Joe mixes or builds
something and it comes up

2739.31.text:
You're a chemist
from what I'm seeing

2744.03.text:
And you're not sure what
happened and what I stirred up.

2746.36.text:
You're getting an idea
now when it's coming out.

2749.45.text:
What's the future
you see for these?

2751.06.text:
You had mentioned
something where you

2752.60.text: wanted to use it for therapy?

2754.45.text:
And what's some of
the future you see?

2756.64.text:
DANIEL AMBROSI:
So I think there's

2758.06.text:
a couple of parts
to that question.

2762.39.text:
One is where kind of the
workflow goes from here.

2765.27.text: Where I can take it next.

2767.66.text:
And then there's the question
of how can it be applied.

2771.06.text:
So in terms of what
I'm doing with it now

2773.12.text:
as an artist in terms
of trying to push

2774.80.text:
it is I continue to go
on photo expeditions,

2780.16.text:
and look for special places,
and capture them, and ideally

2786.28.text:
But in the last year working
with a number of art galleries

2789.94.text:
and some really astute
gallerists and curators,

2794.05.text:
I've gotten some ideas
for really taking

2797.78.text:
this to a place at first
I never even thought of.

2800.33.text:
In fact, when I heard
the idea I objected.

2802.99.text:
I realized later that
this one curator was right

2806.93.text:
and probably helps
that she's PhD

2809.38.text:
from the Sorbonne
and everything else.

2810.96.text: But she gave me this idea.

2812.15.text:
She said, what if you took,
if this is 8 feet high,

2816.15.text:
what if you took a 1 foot square
detail and blew that up to 40

2822.35.text:
by 40 inches and
maybe dreamed on it

2824.99.text:
afresh with more intensity,
what would you get?

2827.60.text:
It might be a really
cool mid-sized piece.

2830.01.text:
And I gave her all sorts of
reasons why it wasn't possible,

2832.94.text:
and that's not what
I do, and all this.

2834.56.text:
Turned out to be the
best thing I ever did.

2837.14.text:
I just last week released a new
series called Mining Nightfall,

2841.19.text:
where I took that
Central Park twilight

2843.14.text:
scene you might have noticed
in the video and mined it.

2849.50.text:
I ended up with 11
of those scenes.

2852.59.text:
And it's a wonderful,
thematic kind of set.

2856.82.text:
So I'm sure there are more
ideas like that that others can

2861.44.text:
suggest or I can come
up with over time.

2864.14.text:
In terms of the
application, again, this

2867.05.text:
does have its basis
in healing art.

2872.00.text:
It's not what I
initially set out to do.

2874.34.text:
What I set out to
do was I wanted

2876.71.text:
to get that feeling
across that I have.

2879.17.text:
And that feeling
happens to be one reason

2880.94.text:
we love to go hiking and
go into nature and stuff

2883.16.text:
like that is because it
makes us feel so good.

2885.38.text:
That's why they call
them restorative places.

2889.97.text:
And so the application
I'm most excited about

2894.54.text:
is this VR, virtual
reality application

2900.44.text:
And, like I said, distraction
therapy for pain management.

2908.06.text:
With this opiate
epidemic, you don't

2910.82.text:
want to be handing out a lot
more painkillers than you need.

2915.11.text:
And it's known that the brain
can only process so much stuff.

2918.59.text:
And if you're distracted
doing something else,

2920.51.text:
you're not going to
feel the pain as much.

2922.61.text:
So they've actually
had good results

2924.17.text:
experimenting with burn victims
putting them in a VR headset,

2931.37.text:
And the need for opiate
drugs and painkillers

2937.92.text:
Now in addition to making it
something cool and interactive,

2940.76.text:
if you also make
it something that's

2942.26.text:
got its basis in
healing art, it's

2946.50.text: just going to be a win-win.

2948.29.text:
JOSEPH SMARR: And I
think more broadly,

2950.02.text:
this idea of collaborating
with AI and having it

2955.10.text:
as a metaphor for the
future of knowledge

2956.84.text:
work where we don't necessarily
have our hands completely

2959.21.text:
on the controls,
and we have to learn

2960.80.text:
how to steer it, and work with
it, and accept its limitations,

2963.47.text:
but also let us go further
than we've been before.

2965.55.text:
And how it helps us think
about the way we see reality.

2968.19.text:
And in music, and in
video, and imagery,

2970.55.text:
there's so much more
opportunity there.

2972.17.text:
So this definitely
convinced me that we're just

2974.54.text:
DANIEL AMBROSI: So we were told
to wrap up at four o'clock.

2979.88.text:
JOSEPH SMARR: Thank
you very much.
